security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing mentoring guidelines for code review processes. No executable code exists - only markdown documentation with response templates and questions. The pre-computed static analysis flagged 25 findings, but ALL are false positives: testing terminology (expect, assert, AAA pattern) was misidentified as cryptographic algorithms, Socratic questions were misidentified as system reconnaissance, and markdown formatting was misidentified as shell execution. This skill poses no security risk.

content.user_title: Guide Junior Developers to Write Tests
content.value_statement: Junior developers often skip testing due to time pressure or lack of confidence. This skill provides a mentoring framework that encourages testing through positive reinforcement rather than blocking requirements.
actual_capabilities: Provides structured questions to ask developers about their testing approach
Offers response templates for different testing scenarios (pass, no tests, weak tests)
Includes stack-specific testing suggestions for React, Next.js, APIs, and Python
Connects testing practices to interview preparation and career development
Uses WARNING status instead of blocking to encourage rather than enforce testing
Delivers Socratic guidance for developers who want to add tests but do not know where to start
limitations: Does not automatically detect or run tests - requires manual review
Focuses on encouragement rather than enforcement - may not suit all team cultures
Limited to mentoring conversations - no technical implementation

use_cases.title: Code Review Mentoring
use_cases.description: Guide junior developers through testing practices during code reviews with structured questions and encouraging feedback.

use_cases.target_user: Tech leads onboarding new team members
use_cases.title: Developer Onboarding
use_cases.description: Establish testing culture in new teams by using positive reinforcement techniques that build habits over time.

use_cases.title: Interview Preparation
use_cases.description: Help developers build testing experience that translates to strong interview stories about code quality practices.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Testing Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Ask the developer: "What tests did you write for this feature?" Look for at least one meaningful test file that actually runs.

prompt_templates.title: Coverage Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Follow up with: "What does your test prove about this feature?" and "If I broke [specific part], which test would catch it?"

prompt_templates.title: Test Quality Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Ask: "Show me your most important test. What behavior does it verify?" Look for behavior testing over implementation details.

prompt_templates.title: Socratic Guidance
prompt_templates.prompt: Use these questions to guide: 1) "What's the ONE thing that would be really bad if it broke?" 2) "What input would a user never send but a hacker might?" 3) "What happens when the server is slow or returns an error?"

output_examples.input: Developer has no tests for their new API endpoint
output: No tests found for this feature. That's okay - we can proceed.
1. Interview Gold: I implemented tests for critical flows...
2. Confidence: Know your changes do not break things
3. Documentation: Tests show how code should be used
- That is already better than most!

output_examples.input: Developer wrote weak tests that only check true equals true
output: Tests exist but could be stronger:
Issue: Tests check behavior, not implementation
Question: If input was malformed, would your tests catch it?
This does not block you, but consider:

output_examples.input: Developer has good test coverage with happy path and edge cases
output: Nice work including tests! I see you covered:
- Happy path for the main function
Key strength: Tests verify behavior, not implementation
Consider adding: Property-based testing for edge cases

best_practices: Always start with encouragement - acknowledge what the developer did well before suggesting improvements
Use specific examples from their code when giving feedback about test coverage
Connect testing to career benefits like interview preparation to increase motivation
anti_patterns: Do not block developers from proceeding - this creates resistance to testing rather than building habits
Avoid generic feedback - always reference specific parts of their code or functionality
Do not overwhelm with too many suggestions - focus on one or two actionable improvements

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all development stacks?
faq.answer: Yes, the mentoring approach works across all technologies. Stack-specific hints are provided for common frameworks.

faq.question: How does this handle time-constrained situations?
faq.answer: The skill explicitly acknowledges that production pressure exists and does not block progress.

faq.question: Can this integrate with existing code review processes?
faq.answer: Yes, it is designed as a gate in a review process. Use the provided questions and response templates.

faq.question: Is developer data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: This skill processes no data - it is purely documentation with conversation templates for mentoring.

faq.question: What if developers keep skipping tests?
faq.answer: The skill emphasizes building habits over time. Document discussions and celebrate small wins.

faq.question: How is this different from automated testing tools?
faq.answer: This focuses on the human side - mentoring and encouragement to build the testing mindset.
